notificatie.titel: UK variant gains terrain in the Netherlands
notificatie.bericht: The number of newly tested COVID positives slightly decreased to 35.635 cases in the week of 20 to 26 January compared to the week before. This overview is overshadowed by the rising number of cases involving the SARS-CoV-2 variant that resulted in a massive influx of patients in hospitals in the United Kingdom and Ireland. It is estimated that the people that got infected with COVID-19 in the past week (20 to 26 January), more than a third is infected with the UK variant. We are facing two variants of the virus that seem to be spreading in the Netherlands at different speeds. As a result, there are essentially two separate COVID-19 epidemics: one epidemic involving the ‘old’ variant, in which infections are decreasing, and another epidemic involving the UK variant, in which infections are increasing.

ic_opnames_per_dag.datums: Calculated: {{dateOfReport}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
ic_opnames_per_dag.pagina_toelichting: Daily number of COVID-19 patients admitted to a hospital intensive care unit (ICU), directly or from a regular hospital ward. To avoid doubles only the first IC admission of a patient counts. This number gives information about the severity of the disease en helps track the development of the epidemic.
ic_opnames_per_dag.barscale_screenreader_text: {{value}} intensive care-admissions by day. Alert value: {{signaalwaarde}} admissions per day.
ic_opnames_per_dag.extra_uitleg:
Number of confirmed COVID-19 cases who are admitted to a hospital intensive care unit (ICU) per day. This figure is an average for the daily admissions over the past three days.

Note: Although hospitals try to register COVID-19 patients promptly, it is likely that the numbers of the last days are yet incomplete.

chart_bedbezetting.description: This graph shows the progression of the number of ICU beds occupied by COVID-19 patients. The data before the 1st of June is less reliable due to setting up the registration by LCPS.

ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.datums: Calculated: {{dateOfReport}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.pagina_toelichting: A rise in the number of patients with COVID-19 could overburden hospitals. This number is also a valid indicator for epidemic growth. This section of the dashboard shows the number of patients with COVID-19 admitted to hospital each day and the number of regular hospital beds occupied by patients with COVID-19. The dashboard provides national and regional figures drawn from various sources.
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.extra_uitleg:
Number of people with COVID-19 admitted to hospital daily. This figure shows how many hospital admissions are reported per day, including patients from outside the hospital admitted directly to the ICU. It may include hospital admissions that occurred in previous days.

*The peak in hospital admissions on 23 February is due to late reports of admissions in the Gelderland-Midden region.*
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.map_titel: Residence of patients admitted to hospital
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.map_toelichting: This map shows, by municipality or safety region, where people live who have been admitted to hospital with COVID-19. Please note that people may have been admitted to a hospital located somewhere else in the Netherlands; the map therefore does not show admission numbers per hospital. The figures here reflect the daily hospital admissions reported to the National Intensive Care Evaluation Registry (Stichting NICE).
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.linechart_titel: Progression in hospital admissions over time
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.barscale_screenreader_text: {{value}} hospital admissions per day. Alert value: {{signaalwaarde}} admissions per day.

ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.linechart_description: This graph shows hospital admissions, including admissions directly to ICU. The figure for each day indicates the number of people actually admitted on that day, not the number of admissions reported on that day. This gives a clear picture of the development of coronavirus in the Netherlands. There are often reporting delays of a few days for hospital admissions; data for the most recent days is therefore incomplete.

besmettelijke_personen.title: Number of infectious people
besmettelijke_personen.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
besmettelijke_personen.legenda_line: The number of infectious people in the Netherlands.
besmettelijke_personen.legenda_marge: The number of infectious people is an estimate. The uncertainty margin indicates how much higher or lower the actual number may be.
besmettelijke_personen.geen_signaalwaarde_beschikbaar: Due to a technical problem the data is currently not showing as intended. This is being investigated.
besmettelijke_personen.toelichting_pagina: A person who carries coronavirus can infect other people within a certain time frame. How long someone is infectious for differs from one person to another. The number of infectious people is estimated using data from various sources. It is not possible to know exactly how many people are infectious, but we can indicate whether there are dozens, hundreds, thousands or even more.

besmettelijke_personen.cijfer_titel: Estimated number of infectious people in the Netherlands:
besmettelijke_personen.cijfer_toelichting: A calculation of how many people with COVID-19 can transmit the virus. This number is calculated by the RIVM.

reproductiegetal.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
reproductiegetal.legenda_r: The reproduction number is not an exact value but a reliable estimate. Reproduction numbers (R) using data from less than two weeks ago are not reliable, therefore, the line depicting R stops at a date two weeks in the past.
reproductiegetal.legenda_marge: The confidence interval shows the range between which the number R falls. This is updated on a weekly basis.
reproductiegetal.reproductie_explainer_alt: Image to support the explanation above
reproductiegetal.pagina_toelichting: The reproduction number shows how fast the virus is spreading. The number shows how many people are on average infected by one patient with COVID-19.
reproductiegetal.barscale_toelichting: Number of people infected by one infectious person.
reproductiegetal.extra_uitleg: The reproduction number shows how fast the virus is spreading. This number shows how many people are on average infected by one patient with COVID-19. The number of transmissions remains more or less constant when the reproduction number is 1, declines when it is less than 1 and increases when the number is above 1.

overige_gegevens.title: To be developed
overige_gegevens.text: We aim to expand the dashboard in the future with the following data:

list.content:
The RIVM monitors the spread of infectious diseases in many ways. This is also the case for COVID-19. One of these ways is to look at persons exhibiting symptoms that could indicate an infection. The RIVM does this with the Infectieradar.

Everyone in the Netherlands can take part in the Infectieradar. Participants self-report once a week if they have (had) a fever or other symptoms. Even if participants don't have any symptoms they pass this on to us. This way, signals of an increase or decrease in the spread of the virus are picked up earlier.

list.text: Contact tracing by the municipal public health service (GGD)
list.content: When someone is infected with COVID-19, the municipal health service (GGD) tries to find out where they got it from and who they recently had contact with. The purpose is to discover whether the virus has also been transmitted to any other people.

Care professionals with COVID-19 can infect their patients, so monitoring care professionals’ health can help contain the spread of the disease. This means keeping track of the number of care professionals who are infected with coronavirus and the number who report ill. This data also helps the healthcare system cope with increases in workload.
Data on the movement of people can indicate how the coronavirus is spreading. The aim is to show this per municipality.
The compliance monitor provides insight into the degree to which people are able to follow the coronavirus measures.

RIVM routinely collects data from behavioural studies that shed light on trends in compliance with and support for the basic rules that apply, like washing hands, staying home and getting tested if you have symptoms.

rioolwater_metingen.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
rioolwater_metingen.pagina_toelichting: Average number of coronavirus particles per 100.000 inhabitants found in wastewater. The weekly average is calculated by adding up all the values measured at roughly 300 locations and dividing this by the number of measurements taken.If someone is infected with coronavirus, coronavirus particles will usually be present in their excrement, which is carried away into the sewers. By testing wastewater samples collected at treatment plants, we can find out how much of the virus is present in a given area. Such testing is still experimental. In the long run we hope that wastewater testing will enable early detection and monitoring of coronavirus.
rioolwater_metingen.barscale_titel: Average number of virus particles per 100.000 inhabitants
rioolwater_metingen.extra_uitleg: The weekly average for all of the Netherlands is calculated by adding up all the values measured in one week and dividing this by the number of measurements taken.
rioolwater_metingen.linechart_titel: Average number of virus particles per 100.000 inhabitants over time

There are often reporting delays of a few days for hospital admissions; data for the most recent days is therefore incomplete.

gemeente_rioolwater_metingen.pagina_toelichting: If someone is infected with coronavirus, coronavirus particles will usually be present in their excrement, which is carried away into the sewers. By testing wastewater samples collected at treatment plants, we can find out how much of the virus is present in a given area. Such testing is still experimental. In the long run we hope that wastewater testing will enable early detection and monitoring of coronavirus.

The risk level in a particular region is based on the number of positive tests and the number of hospital admissions. [More information about the risk levels](/over-risiconiveaus).

escalatie_niveau.toelichting:
Every two weeks the coronavirus situation is assessed to see whether it is developing in a positive or negative direction, most recently on February 17. The risk level in a particular region is based on the number of positive tests and the number of hospital admissions. [More information about the risk levels](/over-risiconiveaus).

**There remains a national lockdown until at least 15 March. [Click here to view the lockdown measures](/landelijk/maatregelen).**

1.toelichting: The situation is manageable. The number of new infections is fewer than 35 per 100,000 inhabitants per week. There is sufficient healthcare capacity

2.toelichting: The situation is becoming difficult to manage. The number of new infections is between 35 and 100 per 100,000 inhabitants per week. Pressure on healthcare capacity is increasing.

3.toelichting: The situation is serious. The number of new infections is between 100 and 250 per 100,000 inhabitants per week. Pressure on healthcare capacity is very high.

4.toelichting: The situation is severe. The number of new infections is higher than 250 per 100,000 inhabitants per week. Pressure on healthcare capacity is extreme.

pagina.toelichting: The Netherlands’ approach is essentially to control the virus as much as possible, avoid overburdening the healthcare system and protect vulnerable groups. We can get coronavirus under control, but only if we all follow the basic rules.

nl_gedrag.datums: This survey was carried out between {{weekStart}} and {{weekEnd}}. Is updated every 3 weeks.

onderzoek_uitleg.toelichting: Every three weeks a survey of a representative sample of the Dutch population is carried out. Survey respondents all answer the same questions about the basic rules that the government has laid down to combat coronavirus. The purpose of the survey is to find out to what extent the public supports and follows these rules. The survey is coordinated and published by RIVM, and carried out by Kantar Public.

infected_age_groups.title: Distribution by age
infected_age_groups.description: The blue (right) bars in this graph show which age group positive tested persons belong to. The gray (left) bars show how large each age group is in relation to the entire Dutch population. The blue and gray bars together show whether age groups have relatively more or less positive tested persons. For example: 16% of all positive tested persons are in their twenties (blue bar) and 13% of all Dutch people are in their twenties (gray bar). In this example, the age group twenties has relatively more positive tested people. The chart is updated daily and covers only the most recently reported cases.
infected_age_groups.example: For example: of all positive tested people is {{infectedPercentage}} between {{ageGroupRange}} years old. Of all Dutch people is {{ageGroupPercentage}} between {{ageGroupRange}} years old.

section_sterftemonitor.title: Mortality monitor
section_sterftemonitor.description: Every week the national office Statistics Netherlands (CBS) publishes data on the total number of deaths in the Netherlands and compares this to the predicted number of deaths, corrected for extreme temperatures, epidemics, etc. If more deaths occur than predicted, these are considered excess deaths. This graph may show a more complete picture of COVID-19 related deaths than the numbers reported by the GGD because not everyone who dies from COVID-19 has been tested for it.
section_sterftemonitor.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.

reference.text: Read more in 'explanation of the data presented'

cbs_message.title: Mortality not declining further in week 7
cbs_message.message:
In week 7 (15 to 21 February inclusive), estimated mortality stood at 3,600. This is over 150 deaths in excess of the expected number for this period and around 100 more than in the previous week (3,521 deaths). Statistics Netherlands (CBS) reports this based on the provisional weekly figures on mortality.
Since week 39 of 2020, weekly mortality has been higher than expected. Last week (week 6), the number of deaths was more or less the same as the expected mortality for this period. Estimated mortality for week 7 is more than 150 deaths above the expected number for this period. The National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) registered 301 COVID-19 deaths in week 7 (as at 23 February).

link.text: Read the full news item on the CBS website

section_sterftemonitor.deceased_monitor_chart_title: Total number of deaths per week
section_sterftemonitor.deceased_monitor_chart_description: This graph shows the total number of deaths per week in the Netherlands in 2020. The actual number of deaths is compared to the number of deaths predicted based on the figures from preceding years. The light blue line, drawn within its range of uncertainty, shows the number of deaths predicted over the year. The dark blue line shows the number of actual deaths.

deceased_age_groups.title: COVID-19 deaths by age
deceased_age_groups.description: The blue bars on the right of this graph show the age distribution of people who have died from COVID 19. The grey bars on the left show how large each age group is in relation to the entire Dutch population. Taken together, the blue and grey bars show whether there are proportionately more or fewer COVID-19 deaths in each age group. If, for example, the graph shows that people in their sixties represent 12% of the Dutch population (grey bar) and that this same group represents 10% of the people in the Netherlands who have died from COVID-19 (blue bar), that means there are proportionately fewer deaths from COVID-19 among people in their sixties. The graph is updated daily and includes all deaths since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. Please note that RIVM groups COVID-19 deaths among people younger than 50 together; the low numbers could otherwise be traceable back to individual people.

vr_risiconiveau.pagina_toelichting: Every 2 weeks we reassess the risk level in each safety region based on the number of positive tests (new confirmed cases) and the number of hospital admissions there. If one of these figures gives cause to set a higher risk level than the other, the higher risk level applies. Certain measures apply at each risk level. The exact measures that apply in this safety region depend on the situation in the rest of the country as well as the situation here.

The actual number of COVID-19 patients that died may be higher because not all people with COVID-19 get tested and there is no requirement for reporting deaths due to COVID-19.
section_deceased_rivm.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.

reference.text: Read more in 'explanation of the data presented'.

section_deceased_rivm.kpi_covid_daily_title: Daily number of COVID-19 patients reported dead
section_deceased_rivm.kpi_covid_daily_description: This figure shows the number of COVID-19 patients in this municipality reported dead to the GGD, per day. It includes late reports of deaths that occurred in the preceding days.
section_deceased_rivm.kpi_covid_total_title: Total number of COVID-19 patients reported dead
section_deceased_rivm.kpi_covid_total_description: This figure shows the number of COVID-19 patients in this municipality reported dead, since the reporting of COVID-19 deaths started.
section_deceased_rivm.line_chart_covid_daily_title: Number of COVID-19 patients reported dead over time
section_deceased_rivm.line_chart_covid_daily_description: This graph shows the number of COVID-19 patients in this municipality reported dead, in the selected period.

header.title: Use of the CoronaMelder app
header.description: The CoronaMelder app has been developed to help fight the spread of coronavirus. The app keeps track of when users have been within close range of one another for a longer period of time. If a CoronaMelder user tests positive for COVID-19, they can choose to alert other app users. App users who get an alert can then get tested and avoid unknowingly infecting others.
header.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.

reference.text: Read more about the CoronaMelder app in the explanation of the presented data.

waarschuwingen.title: Number of people who alerted others via CoronaMelder:
waarschuwingen.description: This figure shows how many CoronaMelder users who tested positive alerted other app users of this yesterday.

rapport.title: Factsheet CoronaMelder
rapport.description: Researchers are closely monitoring the CoronaMelder app’s impact. Read the most recent factsheet about this on the CoronaMelder website.
